quiz.title: Pre-calculus: Unit 5 Quiz 6
quiz.subtitle: 5.6: Change of Base Formula
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Evaluating non-standard logarithms using common and natural logs

questions.question: Which expression is equivalent to $\log_{5}(12)$ using the Change of Base Formula?
Evaluate $\log_{2}(10)$ using a calculator and the Change of Base Formula.
True or False: Using $\ln$ instead of $\log$ in the Change of Base Formula will give you a different answer.
questions.explanation: The ratio of the logarithms remains constant regardless of the base you choose to convert to.

questions.question: Which of these is the correct setup to find $\log_{7}(20)$?
questions.explanation: The 'old' base always goes to the denominator.

questions.question: The Change of Base Formula is $\log_{b}(x) = \frac{\log_{a}(x)}{\log_{a}(b)}$. What is the most common value used for $a$?
questions.explanation: We typically use base 10 or base $e$ because those are the functions available on calculators.

questions.question: Simplify $\frac{\log(15)}{\log(3)}$ into a single logarithm.
questions.explanation: This is the Change of Base Formula in reverse.

questions.question: Without a calculator, between which two integers does $\log_{3}(20)$ fall?
questions.explanation: Since $3^2 = 9$ and $3^3 = 27$, and 20 is between 9 and 27, the log must be between 2 and 3.

questions.question: Is $\frac{\ln(x)}{\ln(b)}$ the same as $\ln(\frac{x}{b})$?
options: No, the second one is the Quotient Property.
questions.explanation: $\ln(x/b) = \ln(x) - \ln(b)$. This is a very common point of confusion!

questions.question: If $\log_{2}(x) = \frac{\ln(10)}{\ln(2)}$, then $x = $
questions.explanation: The right side is the Change of Base expansion for $\log_{2}(10)$.

questions.question: Why can the base $a$ in the formula NOT be 1?
options: Because 1 is not a prime number.
Because the log of 1 is always 1.
Because calculators don't have a base 1 button.
questions.explanation: Logarithms are not defined for base 1 (as $1^y$ is always 1).

scoreMessages.90: Perfect! You can now calculate any log on any calculator.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Just remember: Base goes in the Basement (denominator).
scoreMessages.50: Be careful not to confuse Change of Base with the Quotient Property.
scoreMessages.0: Review the Change of Base formula: $\log_{b}(x) = \log(x)/\log(b)$.
